To praise thy life, or waile thy worthie death,</br>And want thy wit, thy wit high, pure, divine,</br>Is far beyond the powre of mortall line,</br>Nor any one hath worth that draweth breath.
Yet rich in zeale, though poore in learnings lore,</br>And friendly care obscurde in secret brest,</br>And love that envie in thy life supprest,</br>Thy deere life done, and death has doubled more.
And I, that in thy time and living state,</br>Did only praise thy vertues in my thought,</br>As one that seeld the rising sun hath sought,</br>With words and teares now waile thy timelesse fate.
Drawne was thy race aright from princely line,</br>Nor lesse than such (by gifts that nature gave,</br>The common mother that all creatures have,)</br>Doth vertue shew, and princely linage shine.
A king gave thee thy name, a kingly minde,</br>That God thee gave, who found it now too deere,</br>For this base world, and hath resumde it neere,</br>To sit in skies, and sort with powres divine.

Kent thy birth daies, and Oxford held thy youth,</br>The heavens made hast, and staid nor yeers, nor time,</br>The fruits of age grew ripe in thy first prime,</br>Thy will, thy words; thy words the seales of truth.

Great gifts and wisedom rare imployd thee thence,</br>To treat from kings, with those more great than kings,</br>Such hope men had to lay the highest things,</br>On thy wise youth, to be transported hence.
Whence to sharpe wars sweet honor did thee call,</br>Thy countries love, religion, and thy friends:</br>Of worthy men, the marks, the lives and ends,</br>And her defence, for whom we labour all.

There didst thou vanquish shame and tedious age,</br>Griefe, sorrow, sicknes, and base fortunes might:</br>Thy rising day, saw never wofull night,</br>But past with praise, from off this worldly stage.

Backe to the campe, by thee that day was brought,</br>First thine owne death, and after thy long fame,</br>Teares to the soldiers, the proud Castilians shame;</br>Vertue exprest, and honor truly taught.

What hath he lost, that such great grace hath woon,</br>Yoong yeeres, for endles yeeres, and hope unsure,</br>Of fortunes gifts, for wealth that still shall dure,</br>Oh happie race with so great praises run.

England doth hold thy lims that bred the same,</br>Flaunders  thy valure where it last was tried,</br>The campe thy sorrow where thy bodie died,</br>Thy friends, thy want; the world, thy vertues fame.
Nations thy wit, our mindes lay up thy love,</br>Letters thy learning, thy losse, yeeres to come,</br>In worthy harts Sorrow hath made thy tombe,</br>Thy soule and spright enrich the heavens above.

Thy liberall hart imbalmd in gratefull teares,</br>Yoong sighs, sweet sighes, sage sighes, bewaile thy fall,</br>Envie her sting, and spite hath left her gall,</br>Malice her selfe, a mourning garment weares.
That day their Hanniball died, our Scipio fell,</br>Scipio, Cicero, and Petrarch of our time,</br>Whose vertues wounded by my worthlesse rime,</br>Let Angels speake, and heaven thy praises tell.</br>
